Hi Oliver,

thanks for your response. I also think that self-organizing pri=
nciples are an important factor in the development of neural networks. I th=
ink, these mechanisms are one reason, why the evolution of neural networks =
is so robust. However, with the link to the polychronization article I want=
ed to highlight that heterogeneous conduction delays might point to a new w=
ay of processing information / implementing certain functions and that patt=
ern generating encodings might be a very good way of making use of heteroge=
neous conduction delays.

Here are some thoughts to some of your statements=
:

> What seems
> more important is the interplay of these properties of di=
fferent types of
> neurons and synapses that allows the network to self-org=
anise in such a way
> that it performs the required functions. The self-org=
anisation creates the
> detailed form and function of the brain (eg topolog=
y and connection
> strengths). 

I agree with you. It also means that the v=
ery same network region can show different behavior depending on the input =
it receives (e.g. visual cortices can be involved in auditory task when no =
retinal input drives the system). For computational studies this means, we =
should seek for networks that are able to adapt to different types of input=
.


> It seems more like natural genomes encode the neuron and
> synapse ty=
pes, and which regions of the brain they go in, and the
> properties of the=
se neuron and synapse types. 

That's why I developed the "Brain in a box" =
model, a naive approach, in which a CPPN just encodes the position and orie=
ntation of dendritic and axonal projection cones. Intersections of cones le=
ad to connections between neurons. But there are better ways to implement t=
his.

>I suspect there are still
> some regions where the genome encodes, o=
ne way or another, a fairly precise
> topology (though even in this case th=
e genome could make use of how the
> neurons and synapses self-organise).

=
you mean, like in c. elegans, which has exactly 302 neurons.!? I am wonderi=
ng, whether it is correct to say that in simpler organisms natural encoding=
s tend to encode the precise topology whereas with increasing complexity th=
e encoding leaves more organizational tasks to self-organizing mechanisms.
=

> 
> As part of my current work I'm planning on reproducing many of these
=
> properties, including synaptic transmission delays, in a neural network
>=
 model to see how they affect the evolvability and capabilities of evolved
=
> networks performing online learning. I'm planning on using HyperNEAT or a=

> variant like ES-HyperNEAT, and am in the middle of implementing these ki=
nds
> of properties in a neural network model and creating a flexible Hyper=
NEAT
> set-up to allow specifying the parameters for models of these proper=
ties.
> The motivation being that a lot of these properties have been impli=
cated in
> learning processes in the brain. See http://ojcoleman.com/node/1=
 and
> http://ojcoleman.com/node/3 for details and links to the software. ;=
)

Thanks for the links (btw: I commented in your third posting ;)). But I =
did not find any link to the software you use? Do you work in Matlab, Pytho=
n or something else?

With a colleague, we work on a model that implements =
structural plasticity, heterogeneous conduction delays and STDP in spiking =
neurons (we use the Izhikevich neuron and everything is implemented in Matl=
ab). Synapses are build depending on the activation level of the neuron and=
 its projection kernel. I think, the projection kernel could be something t=
hat can be encoded by a CPPN. Having this kind of super-gun, we are now fac=
ing the question: how to setup an appropriate fitness-function, which runs =
a bit into the discussions we had here the last weeks. :-)

Best,
Martin
